newsitem.title: BOSNIA: Bosnian court opens trial of rebel Moslem leader.
newsitem.headline: Bosnian court opens trial of rebel Moslem leader.

text.p: A Bosnian court opened proceedings on Wednesday against rebel Moslem leader Fikret Abdic on charges connected with his armed rebellion against the Sarajevo government.
A judge for the Moslem-led Bosnian government read out a lengthy indictment against Abdic, who is being tried in his absence in a court in the northwest town of Bihac, state radio reported.
It included allegations that Abdic orchestrated the shelling and detention of civilians, pressed men into military service and ordered a blockade of humanitarian aid to the Bihac region.
Abdic has registered a political party to contest Bosnia's post-war elections and analysts said it was no accident that authorities began the trial less than two weeks before the September 14 polls.

Abdic, a businessman-turned-politician and an arch rival of Bosnian President Alija Izetbegovic, led a rebellion against the Sarajevo government in 1993 and declared the Bihac enclave "an autonomous region".
He armed his troops by reaching deals with Croat and Serb armies fighting the government, which recaptured the enclave in 1995. Abdic and his followers then fled to Croatia.
